commentBody:
Not a surprise since the admission standards for most Universities and other similar schools in America for athletes are not the same as for other applicants. Schools, UNC. for example, admitting athletes who read at the 3rd grade level. Perhaps it is time for colleges to admit that athletes cannot really do a real academic load. It is time to shed the pretense-and for universities to come clean-either have an admission standard-or develop one for athletes who may not qualify. And if that is the case-how do they get a college education. In the case of UNC-as published reports tend to show-having tailor-made course for them-which is a disgusting revelation.
The whole US University program with athletes leaves a bad taste with regard to what a degree means to a college athlete. Some are real students-but how to quantify a degree to an athlete who did not take the major core courses? American universities must come to grips with this problem-there is no way a full-time athlete at a major university in American can carry a real-full time load of academics. To offer to cheapen the athlete's load is to cheapen all degrees offered by that university to all students. And that is the real problem.
